title: Initial Claims Remain Range Bound
text: Initial claims for regular state unemployment insurance totaled 745,000 for the week ending February 27, up 9,000 from the previous week's upwardly revised tally of 736,000. The four-week average fell 16,750 to 790,750, the fourth weekly decline in a row and the first week below 800,000 since early December.

title: 'The underlying trend of the consumer is very healthy,': Mastercard Sr. Adviser
text: Mastercard Sr. Adviser & Fmr Saks Chairman and CEO, Steve Sadove, joined Yahoo Finance Live to break down the current state of the retail industry and how COVID-19 has impacted it.

title: Several Indexes Broke Key Levels Today (Technically Speaking For 3/4)
text: There's some underlying technical weakness in the markets. Initial unemployment claims didn't improve from last week's reading.

title: Senate likely to pass $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief package this weekend, with no Republican vote
text: Senate Republicans argue President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion coronavirus package has many provisions that push the agenda for Democrats. The Senate is likely to pass the bill over the weekend, however, with no Republican votes.

title: Jim Cramer explains the connection between bonds and stocks
text: "The professionals are taking their cue from the bond market, not the much smaller stock market, so you can't afford to be in denial about this linkage," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Companies going public, lockup expirations will weigh on the market, Jim Cramer says
text: "Right as the market's rolling over ... we're about to get hit with the last thing we need … a stock glut," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Jim Cramer: How to spot a bottom in the stock market
text: "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer explained why selling in the bond market is causing stocks to sell off, and how psychology and the five stages of grief can help signal when the bull run could resume.

title: Cramer says investors are in denial about stocks: 'The sell-off is real'
text: The stock market rally can't resume until investors work through the five stages of grief, CNBC's Jim Cramer said.

title: Top banks' 2020 commodities revenue soars 85% - consultancy Coalition
text: Commodities-related revenue at the world's 12 biggest investment banks surged by 85% last year compared to 2019 as oil and metals trading made further strong gains, consultancy Coalition said on Friday.

title: Cornerstone Macro's Carter Worth breaks down the tech wreck
text: Cornerstone Macro's Carter Worth with his technical take on the Nasdaq. With CNBC's Kate Rooney and Melissa Lee, and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Dan Nathan.

title: Cramer warns a looming 'stock glut' will put more pressure on markets
text: "The stock market is about to have a serious oversupply problem with no concomitant buybacks or dividends to fall back on this moment," Jim Cramer said.

title: Finding opportunity in the tech sell-off
text: Dan Niles, Satori Fund founder, on where investors can look for tech stock opportunities. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Guy Adami, Tim Seymour, Karen Finerman and Dan Nathan.

title: Tech Stocks Take A Beating: This Is How To Make Tricky Trading Decisions In Tough Markets
text: Zor Capital's Joe Fahmy analyzes economic reopening plays for investors' watchlists as the major indexes, and tech stocks in particular, get hit. The post Tech Stocks Take A Beating: This Is How To Make Tricky Trading Decisions In Tough Markets appeared first on Investor's Business Daily.

title: Market Extra: 5 reasons why negative repo rates are different than the last overnight-funding crisis
text: Rates to borrowers in the overnight U.S. Treasury market went negative heading into Thursday, a situation BofA Global analysts were predicting would happen "by May,” without tweaks from the central bank.

title: Stock futures are flat after a steep sell-off on Wall Street amid surging bond yields
text: The move in futures followed a sharp sell-off triggered by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks on rising bond yields.

title: U.S. stocks fall after Powell's inflation warning — Here's what investors are watching now
text: U.S. stocks tumbled after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said the reopening could cause temporary inflation. Here's what investors are saying about the markets.

title: Companies Are Issuing Guidance Again. What Investors Should Know.
text: Should investors hold their breath or sigh in relief?

title: Stock Market Sells Off On Powell Speech As Treasury Yields Spike; DraftKings, PayPal Trigger Sell Signals
text: The stock market ended sharply lower Thursday following Fed chief Powell's comments, as the 10-year Treasury yield spiked. PayPal dived over 6%.

title: The Anti-ARK Innovation Stocks Are Winning
text: Even though the recession ended in May 2020, the early cycle trade only started in November 2020 following the positive vaccine news. Value is cheap versus growth on a historical basis. Plus, it's a great contrarian play.

title: Powell Talks Inflation And Wall Street Continues To Stumble
text: The Newtonian concept of what-goes-up-must-come-down is on full display over the past two weeks as the markets continue to drop from all-time highs. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell greased the slide with predictions of increased inflation in the near future.

title: Trading Options on the Reddit/Robinhoood Stocks Requires Discipline
text: Trading Options on the Reddit/Robinhoood Stocks Requires Discipline

title: Fed's Powell pledges patience, says easy policy appropriate
text: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Thursday repeated his pledge to keep credit loose and flowing until Americans are back to work, rebutting investors who have openly doubted he can stick to that promise once the pandemic passes and the economy surges on its own.

title: Powell pledges Fed easy policy patience, markets look impatient
text: U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on Thursday repeated his pledge to keep credit loose and flowing until Americans are back to work, rebutting investors who have openly doubted if he can stick to that promise once the pandemic passes and the economy surges on its own.

title: Market Recap: Thursday, March 4: Stocks slide following Fed Chair Powell's comments
text: Stocks slumped Thursday after another technology-led selloff on Wednesday. The Nasdaq ended lower by more than 2%, extending losses for a third straight day after the tech-heavy index dropped 2.7% during the regular session on Wednesday.

title: Fed's going to have to sound 'less dovish to get control of bond market': Peter Boockvar
text: Peter Boockvar, Bleakley Advisory Group CIO, calls in to 'The Exchange' to discuss whether he thinks the Fed is starting to lose control of the bond market and what that could mean for the U.S. economy.

title: Pre-Payrolls Selloff: Fed Remarks Send Treasury Yield Above 1.5% And Nasdaq-100 Into Correction Mode
text: Though a few sectors and the overall market did come back toward the end of the session, there doesn't feel like a lot of positive momentum going into Friday. Instead, the employment report early tomorrow will likely tell the tale of where we go next.

title: Fmr. Goldman Sachs CFO Marty Chavez says the future of fintech is banks
text: Walmart has recruited two Goldman Sachs bankers to help launch its new fintech startup. The retail giant is looking for ways to drive revenue.

title: Equity investors are grappling with inflation and the bond market, says Fundstrat's Tom Lee
text: Dan Ives of Wedbush Securities and Tom Lee, managing director and head of research at Fundstrat, join 'Closing Bell' to give their take on the market sell-off. Dan Ives says now is the time to buy more into tech stocks like DocuSign and Apple.

title: The Nasdaq must recoup this one level to prevent an even bigger downturn, strategist says
text: Another sell-off in tech stocks Thursday pulled the Nasdaq sharply lower. Matt Maley of Miller Tabak breaks down the charts.

title: The Dow Fell 345 Points Because the Fed Couldn't Save the Day
text: Fed Chair Jerome Powell said the agency wouldn't deviate from its current policy. Rates spiked and stocks, particularly growth, tumbled.

title: Stock Market Today: Crash? Not Today.
text: A small rise in weekly jobless claims and comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell sparked a scare in stocks Thursday, though the losses could've been worse.

title: Stocks: Dow falls 700 points at low and 10-year yield spikes following Fed Chair Powell's comments
text: Yahoo Finance's Jared Blikre reports on the 10-year yield spiking and what's driving stocks down.

title: Mohamed El-Erian discusses what's driving the market sell-off
text: Mohamed El-Erian, former PIMCO CEO, says it's not what Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said that's causing concern, but it's how he said it that's causing a massive tech sell-off. "He said something that's worrisome for the fixed income market, it's worrisome for what I've been betting on for a long time," El-Erian said.

title: Stock Market Crisis? Don't Panic!
text: The market has taken a beating today and it's affecting all of us. Portfolios are down as big tech names and other growth stocks are pulling back.

title: Fed Chair Powell Offered a Patient Message. Markets Quivered Anyway.
text: Stocks fell and bond yields rose after the Fed leader reiterated that the central bank did not plan to pull back policy support soon.

title: Stock losses accelerate after Fed Chair Jerome Powell's inflation comments
text: Yahoo Finance's Jared Blikre breaks down the market sell-off following Fed Chair Jerome Powell's comments on inflation.

title: Dow logs first close below 50-day moving average in over a month after Thursday's interest rate-fueled selloff
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 on Thursday marked their first finishes below their short-term moving averages in weeks after a market rout apparently precipitated by rising fears that the Federal Reserve may be losing control of inflation and may be forced to jack up borrowing costs faster than they would prefer to cool an overheated economy recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns. The Dow closed down 1.1% at around 30,924 to mark its third straight decline, falling below its 50-day moving average at 30,944.98 for the first time since Feb. 1, while the S&P 500 index closed Thursday's trade 1.3% lower for its third consecutive drop, finishing at 3,769, concluding the session below its 50-day MA at 3,818.61 for the first time since Jan. 29.

title: Wall Street suffers afternoon selloff after Fed Chair Jerome Powell says repopening could cause inflation
text: 4:10pm: Traders sharply reversed course in the afternoon The Dow closed down 346 points, 1.1%, at 30,924 after opening in the green. The Nasdaq lost 274 points, 2.1%, to 12,723, and the S&P 500 slid 51 points, 1.3%, to 3,768.

title: More GameStop-like short squeezes could be up ahead in the 'fragile' stock market, says a market research veteran
text: The GameStop short-squeeze that shook markets in January probably won't be the last of its kind, according to Wellington Management's Owen Lamont.  The market researcher said he anticipates more short squeezes in the future in illiquid names and "little corners of the market," on an episode of the Exchanges at Goldman Sachs podcast published Wednesday.

title: Goldilocks Died a Year Ago, Says Gabelli Funds' Marangi
text: Mar.04 -- “The era of low inflation, and low rates, and good growth is probably over,” says Christopher Marangi, co-cio at Gabelli Funds. He speaks with Jonathan Ferro on “Bloomberg Surveillance.

title: Stocks sell off in the wake of Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech
text: Yahoo Finance's Brian Cheung breaks down Fed Chair Jerome Powell's remarks on monetary policy, signaling no eagerness to raise inflation.

title: Nuveen's Brian Nick says he's still a big believer in the recovery
text: Brian Nick, chief investment strategist at Nuveen, says he expects inflation to continue to rise, especially after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's comments today on expecting temporary inflation. He says he would maintain positions in tech for the long-term while investing in more cyclical stocks for short-term gain.

title: Rates are going up because the market is broadening, says Stephanie Link
text: Stephanie Link, Hightower chief investment strategist and portfolio manager, says it's important to see the manufacturing sector of the U.S. economy doing well. She joins 'Closing Bell' to explain why rates are going up.

title: Dow plunges 346 points as Fed Chairman Jerome Powell preaches 'patience' on inflation spike
text: US stocks fell sharply Thursday as investors reacted to comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. Powell refrained from outlining specific steps to rein in what he described as "disorderly" markets. The 10-year Treasury yield spiked back above 1.5% following his statements, spurring a sharp sell-off in the market's most highly valued sectors, like tech.

title: U.S. stocks end sharply lower as bond yields surge; Nasdaq turns lower for year
text: U.S. stocks end sharply lower as bond yields surge; Nasdaq turns lower for year

title: Guggenheim's Minerd: Stocks Will End the Year Higher
text: Mar.04 -- Guggenheim Global Chief Investment Officer Scott Minerd says the Federal Reserve won't tolerate a stock market down more than 15%. He speaks on "Bloomberg Markets.

title: Opportunity in some 'beaten up' stocks, says portfolio manager
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team breaks down markets with Mike Labella of Franklin Templeton Investment Solutions and Valerie Grant of AllianceBernstein.

title: Tech is 'nothing more than natural repricing of risk: UBS Private Wealth's Lipsey
text: Dan Genter, RNC Genter Capital Management, and Roderick von Lipsey, UBS Private Wealth Management managing director, join 'The Exchange' to discuss the tech wreck and their outlook for the sector.

title: Warren Buffett Provides Update on 2021 Annual Meeting
text: The 2021 Berkshire Hathaway Inc. (NYSE:BRK.A)(NYSE:BRK.B) Annual Meeting of Shareholders will be held on May 1, 2021. Unfortunately, we do not currently believe it will be safe at that time to hold a meeting with nearly 40,000 attendees as we last did in 2019.

title: 10-year Treasury yield jumps past 1.5% as Fed chief Powell pledges 'patient' stance on rising inflation
text: The yield on the 10-year Treasury note reclaimed the 1.5% level on Thursday, hitting again at its highest in more than a year, after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell indicated the central bank will keep a steady hand in the face of rising inflation. Powell, in a virtual appearance at the Wall Street Journal Jobs Summit in New York, said he expects the Fed will "be patient" in waiting for inflation to trend above 2%.
